title: Can an overpayment of use of food stamps be added to chapter 7 filing?
question: Last year I had food stamps, but I was over issued, which now results in paying back some of the money. Can the overpayment of $1,000 be added to chapter 7
answers: You must list the overpayment as a debt and add it to the Chapter 7. Whether it is dischargeable depends on facts that you have not given us.
I concur with my colleagues. You can list the overpayment as a debt.

Yes, all debts must be disclosed including overpayment of food stamps. Whether or not such a debt is dischargeable is not known from the limited information you included. If there was any fraud on your part in obtaining the overpayment, the State may challenge the discharge. If you have already filed, and omitted the food stamp debt, you will need to amend your schedules accordingly. If you do not know how to do that, get an appt with a BK lawyer in your area. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it. BK is not a DIY project.

You must list all debt when you file a petition for relief under the bankruptcy code. The question is can the debt be discharged in a chapter 7 and/or in a chapter 13. The answer is, "it depends."

If the over payment of a benefit, whether that benefit is unemployment benefits, food stamps or another type of benefits, the debt can be excepted from discharge if the benefits were received as a result of the recipient providing false information to the governmental entity that provided the benefits or the recipient failed to report information that was required by the governmental entity that would have resulted in the termination of benefits. To establish nondischargeability of the debt, the governmental entity must file an adversary proceeding (AP) within 60 days of the meeting of creditors requesting a determination by the bankruptcy court that the debt is not dischargeable or must file a motion to extend the deadline and file the AP prior to the new deadline as ordered by the court.

I can give you a couple of examples of clients of mine that received an over payment of unemployment benefits with different results. The first client was receiving unemployment comp, found a job and failed to report the fact that he/she was now receiving income. The debt related to the over payment was determined to be nondischargeable. The second client was granted unemployment benefits and the employer appealed. The employer won on appeal and the employee was required to repay the over paid benefits. In the bankruptcy, the MS Department of Employment Security conceded that the debt was dischargeable because the debtor believed she was entitled to benefits and made no misrepresentations.
